posts.name: Isaiah Ballestrazze
posts.cooked:
I have recently started working on building a small Romi swerve bot. While aiming to create a scaled-down version of our existing drivetrain, the main goal is to help younger team members learn programming basics. We plan to utilize the Yet Another Generic Swerve Library (YAGSL) for consistency with our current setup. 

Currently, I'm encountering an issue with the quadrature encoders. On Romi drives, certain pins can be assigned and configured through the Online Web UI. I set all relevant pins to DIO mode and implemented a command in the code to read these pins and display True/False values. This initially worked well, allowing me to observe changes as the motor wheel was turned. However, when attempting to access the Encoder constructor and retrieve raw values using encoder.get(), only zeros were returned. I'm seeking any troubleshooting suggestions to resolve this issue. Unfortunately, I cannot include additional images due to restrictions. Below is the related code:

```python
from romi import Encoder, Romi

def main():
    # Initialize Romi and encoder
    romi = Romi('/dev/ttyUSB0', 57600)
    
    # Create encoder instance
    encoder = Encoder(romi, 3, 2)
    
    # Read raw encoder values
    print(encoder.get())
    
if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```

This repository can be found here: [Romi2025](https://github.com/IsaiahBallestrazze/Romi2025).

link_counts.title: Pololu - Magnetic Encoder Pair Kit for Micro Metal Gearmotors, 12 CPR, 2.7-18V

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: I suspect you would need to create custom Romi firmware to support more than two encoders. For more details on configuring the Romi 32U4 board, consult the GitHub repository linked below. The Romi 32U4 differs from RoboRIO in how its ports are mapped, with some pins able to serve multiple functions. To accommodate WPILib requirements, specific pins are designated for different uses, including analog and digital inputs. Additionally, hardware modifications have been made to accommodate extra inputs and actuators, such as distance sensors or servos, by adding headers to certain pins.

posts.name: Isaiah Ballestrazze
posts.cooked: I’ve never done anything like that before. Is there a guide I could follow, or a better alternative that’s not too bulky?

posts.name: Kyle Swaidner
posts.cooked: There are a couple of XRP system swerve adaptations out there. I believe the XRP board supports four encoders natively.

posts.name: Isaiah Ballestrazze
posts.cooked: I'm just looking at the XRP board, I can use the onboard motor controllers to control the azimuth motors. Then, I could use the DIO ports for direction and a PWM for the speed. I just need to figure out how to set up digital outputs for the board in WPilib Java. Additionally, I need to determine how to use the PWM port directly without relying on the servo class feature. I'll conduct further research on these topics.

posts.name: Kyle Swaidner
posts.cooked: I believe there is still a substantial (50%) discount for FRC teams.

posts.name: Martin
posts.cooked: I would love to see this because this is something I have been wanting to do for fun. It can also help teach eager rookies on how to program a swerving mechanism without giving them a massive full-sized robot to do it with.
